prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The baby suffered a cardiac arrest at the theme park on Thursday

A woman has been arrested on suspicion of neglecting a five-month-old boy who suffered a cardiac arrest at a theme park.

The baby is in a critical condition in hospital following the incident at Legoland Windsor at about 13:00 BST on Thursday, police said.

A 27-year-old woman from Witham, Essex, was arrested on suspicion of neglecting a child to cause unnecessary injury.

She has been released on bail until 26 July.

Det Con Zoe Eele, of Thames Valley Police's Child Abuse Investigation Unit, said: "Firstly, our thoughts are with the family of the boy who is in a critical condition in hospital after suffering a cardiac arrest.

"We are working closely with the team at Legoland Windsor Resort but would like to speak to anyone who have information about this incident, specifically anyone who was queueing for the Coastguard HQ boat ride between around 11.30am and 12:45pm.

"I would ask for the public to please avoid speculation about the incident and to respect the boy's family at this deeply upsetting time."

Police said they are not looking for further suspects in relation to the incident.

In a statement, the theme park said: "On Thursday, a young guest was taken ill... and our fully trained First Aid team administered immediate care until the emergency services arrived.

"We will continue to support Thames Valley Police with their ongoing investigation."

Follow BBC South on Facebook, X, or Instagram. Send your story ideas to south.newsonline@bbc.co.uk or via WhatsApp on 0808 100 2240.

The BBC is not responsible for the content of external sites.
stories:
A toddler was rushed to the hospital after nearly drowning in a wave pool at a popular waterpark on Saturday.

The two-year-old girl is in stable condition following the incident at SplashWorld in Anaheim, California, authorities said.

A 29-year-old man from Los Angeles was arrested on suspicion of child endangerment and released on bail pending a court appearance.

The incident occurred at around 3:45pm when lifeguards pulled the unconscious child from the wave pool and began CPR.

Witnesses described the scene as "chaotic" as paramedics rushed to the scene to take over the rescue efforts.

Sgt. James Reed, of the Anaheim Police Department, urged anyone who may have witnessed the incident to come forward, saying "We need to piece together what happened in those critical moments leading up to the child's rescue."

SplashWorld officials released a statement saying they are cooperating fully with the investigation and reviewing their safety protocols to prevent similar incidents in the future.

The family of the toddler has asked for privacy during this difficult time, and authorities have not released their names.

A five-year-old boy was airlifted to the hospital after a severe allergic reaction to a bee sting at a crowded summer camp in the mountains of Colorado on Thursday.

The young camper is listed in critical condition following the incident at Camp Wilderness, authorities said.

A 35-year-old counselor from Denver was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into the camp's emergency response procedures.

The incident occurred at around 2:15pm when the boy's group was on a nature hike and he suddenly collapsed, prompting his counselor to call for medical help.

Fellow campers described the scene as "hysterical" as paramedics rushed to the scene to transport the boy to a nearby hospital.

Ranger Mark Thompson, of the US Forest Service, urged anyone who may have witnessed the incident to come forward, saying "We need to understand what happened in those crucial minutes before the boy received medical attention."

Camp Wilderness officials released a statement saying they are cooperating fully with the investigation and reviewing their emergency protocols to prevent similar incidents in the future.

The family of the boy has asked for privacy during this difficult time, and authorities have not released their names.

The young festival-goer is listed in stable condition following the incident at Electric Oasis, authorities said.

A 28-year-old festival staff member from Los Angeles was placed on administrative leave pending an investigation into the event's safety protocols.

The incident occurred at around 4:45pm when the girl's group was watching a performance and she suddenly fainted, prompting her friend to call for medical help.

Fellow festival-goers described the scene as "chaotic" as paramedics rushed to the scene to transport the girl to a nearby hospital.

Sergeant Rachel Lee, of the County Sheriff's Department, urged anyone who may have witnessed the incident to come forward, saying "We need to understand what happened in those crucial minutes before the girl received medical attention."

Electric Oasis officials released a statement saying they are cooperating fully with the investigation and reviewing their safety procedures to prevent similar incidents in the future.

The family of the girl has asked for privacy during this difficult time, and authorities have not released their names.

A 15-year-old boy was airlifted to a trauma center after a devastating accident at a packed extreme sports competition in the mountains of Colorado on Sunday.

The young athlete is in critical condition following the incident at Adrenaline Rush, officials reported.

A 35-year-old event coordinator from Denver was suspended pending a thorough review of the competition's safety measures.

The incident occurred at around 2:15pm when the boy attempted a tricky stunt on his skateboard and lost control, crashing to the ground and hitting his head, prompting a nearby medic to call for emergency assistance.

Spectators described the scene as "horrific" as medical personnel rushed to the scene to stabilize the boy before airlifting him to a nearby trauma center.

Deputy Chief Mark Thompson, of the County Police Department, urged anyone who may have witnessed the incident to come forward, saying "We need to piece together what happened in those crucial moments before the boy received medical attention."

Adrenaline Rush officials released a statement saying they are fully cooperating with the investigation and re-examining their safety protocols to prevent similar incidents in the future.

The family of the boy has requested privacy during this difficult time, and authorities have not released their names.

The young rider is in serious condition following the accident at Hoofbeat Haven, officials reported.

A 40-year-old riding instructor from Louisville was placed on administrative leave pending a thorough investigation of the competition's safety procedures.

The incident occurred at around 10:45am when the girl's horse suddenly bucked her off, causing her to fall and hit her spine, prompting a nearby trainer to call for emergency assistance.

Spectators described the scene as "chaotic" as medical personnel rushed to the scene to stabilize the girl before rushing her to a nearby hospital.

Sheriff Rachel Martinez, of the County Sheriff's Department, urged anyone who may have witnessed the incident to come forward, saying "We need to reconstruct what happened in those critical moments before the girl received medical attention."

A 35-year-old rink employee from Colorado was suspended pending a thorough review of the facility's maintenance procedures.
